text: It's very simple to look at a chart on some of these fixed products and see which direction they go. It's only one way down. But an inexperienced investor would tell you like, oh, yeah, great. I could just jump in and short it. Well, that's not the case because these things could rip your face off in an instant. And if you actually jump in and just short it with stock, you run the risk of ruin very fast. But that's not the way we like to express capturing the VRP and capturing this role yield. We actually have a very interesting way of doing it. We've actually backtested this. We have a, quote, unquote, delta optimization point where we believe in selling particular tenors staggered across the board at particular deltas. And we like selling call spreads. So the risk actually remains capped. We actually have a second ETP strategy that we're running. It's an intraday strategy. But the risk comes off immediately. Immediately before the close. So this is a systematized type of product where we just trade it solely intraday. But for the most part, the main balancing act of the book comes from selling the call spreads on the ETPs. And we actually believe that when you get that move and the VIX blows up to the upside, the most of our book is now moving in a relation that we wanted. So those highly convex puts that we bought. That we funded with those straddles. We're losing money on the straddles because straddles are going down. But we have a huge ratio on those downside puts. And those are actually banking for us. And it's covering the losses on the short VIX stuff. Now, what we do well is that we make sure we keep a very low allocation of the VIX stuff. As we were saying, most of our vol stuff is never going to go over more than 30%. But it's on a discretionary base where we want to allocate more or less depending on some of the regimes that's out there and what our VIX is. That's what our research says. But when you now blows out to the upside, all these things become capped off. So when you now get that two standard deviation move, you're fully capped. Your risk is done. Your long calls on the ETP products are covering themselves. And literally, you're just running all profit when the VEGA continues to expand on those highly convex puts. And that's the ideology that we have is that selling these ETPs, the call spreads on the ETPs, help. Our yield in stable markets. Because there are times where you will see the cotango effect is very, very steep. And in stable markets and even in slowly uptrending markets, you'll be able to capture that VRP on the cotango. So it's interesting because, as I was explaining before, our structure is set towards being a little bit negative delta. So when we actually execute our initial trade, which is short to straddle, long all those high VIXs. And then we actually have a lot of long call spreads. And that's the balancing act that the book plays. Interesting enough, it's September 2nd, and there has been a correlation break in spot and vol. All the traders online are talking about this. I've had in-depth conversations with some of the vol guys online about what's taking place. And will this correlation break persist? Generally in a regular environment, Will and I have both noticed that this takes place. It doesn't take place too frequently, but we have given some sort of a nod to it. Like, all right, we have to be aware that this takes place. But for us, we actually like to quote unquote, arb this back into play. When you have those correlation breaks, we would gladly short more. But because of the environment that we're in, with all the instability, with the election time coming up, with possible potential of corporate earnings being horrible, with another resurgence of Corona, all these things that are just constantly taking place, we don't believe now is the time to be shorting that and going long correlations on that. Because correlations break. That's just the nature of it. And some people are probably asking, well, is that a good correlation? Well, it is. Trading the market and trading the SPX in relation to the VIX is a very, very solid correlation. And we don't think that the correlation break will persist. But taking that trade to be long correlations right now in the environment is not the optimal trade for us, at least. And this goes back to what I was saying before. You have to know and when to understand to use your experience as a trader, when as opposed to trusting the math. This is a point where most people will look towards the math and be like, oh, we have to just short it. We're going to short it. But as a trader, we're like, hold on. There's a few things out here that are just not making sense. Let's hedge off our risk on other areas of the book. And let's make sure that we're safe and protected and then we'll go on and we'll assess. But in a nutshell, that is basically the balancing act of the book is we are looking to fund these highly convex puts, capture them on a two week base, a monthly base. And that's the beauty in the tenors that we trade to. Because when you're trading such short dated tenors, the gamma is extremely high and the theta is extremely high. So as you get to capture. The short ball, you're going to have a lot of risk. And if you're going to carry this high theta effect on your short ball stuff, it's really good. Although anybody who's traded the VIX CTP products will know that this carries some sort of a very sticky delta because the market gives a lot of props to the VIX that it can literally spike 20% one day. And so for the VIX CTP stuff, you'll notice that they may be way out the money and you may be safe, but the market makers and the market is just not going to price the falls down completely on that. So you're. Bid ask is still going to be pretty high and you won't be able to really capture that high theta until the last remaining days. But in a nutshell, our ideology is we aim to take advantage of high gamma and also capture high theta. That's like the law of averages for us in a way.
